results.title: Henry Ford 1863-1947
results.brief_description: Deals with the history and development of Henry Ford’s industrial empire. Archival film and re-enactments show events such as the building of the early car models, their effect on society, his relations with organised labour, and the impact of the Great Depression.
results.description: Deals with the history and development of Henry Ford’s industrial empire. Archival film and re-enactments show events such as the building of the early car models, their effect on society, his relations with organised labour, and the impact of the Great Depression.

results.title: Punkline
results.creator_credit: Tony Stevens, Sue Davis and Kali Productions
results.brief_description: Shot at the Crystal Ballroom and Festival Hall during performances of the B 52’s, The Cure, La Femme and The Models, this film provides an observation not of the New Wave performers, but of the people who go to see them. Soundtrack from a tape by Equal Local.

results.title: Climb for the top
results.brief_description: Shows a team of mountain climbers preparing for and actually climbing Mt McKinley, the highest point in North America. Members discuss the elements of teamwork that are necessary to make it to the top. Narration by Sandy Fidell, Jeannie Rose, Don Lauria.

results.title: Aquarium
results.brief_description: Brilliantly photographed non-narrated tableau of unusual underwater creatures including fish that walk on their ‘hands’, sea horses and octopus. Explores the feeding habits and methods of locomotion of these marine life forms. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Shooting scene 341 [from 'the spy who loved me']
results.brief_description: Filmed on location during the shooting of scene 341 from “The Spy who loved me”. An action scene necessitating the construction of a huge and expensive set. Includes fly-on-the-wall footage of direction, rehearsal and shooting of the scene plus commentary from the director (Lewis Gilbert), the director of photography, stunt co-ordinator, and Roger Moore. Produced for Open University.

results.title: Masters of modern sculpture. 3. New world
results.brief_description: Shows the influence of the European artists who came to New York with the end of World War II. Illustrates how they began to use all types of materials including wood, iron, steel, plastic, stone and plaster. Works include those by David Smith, John Chamberlain, Isamo Noguchi, Claus Oldenburg, and Christo. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Helping you to help your child
results.creator_credit: Bill Cole and New Zealand Council for Educational Research
results.brief_description: Contains four sequences intended to introduce parents to the essential features to be observed in tutoring their children. The advice given is directed towards parents with older children having reading difficulties. The procedures suggested are not intended as a basis for tutoring younger children learning to read in a regular school program.

results.title: Remedial reading: a family affair
results.creator_credit: Bill Cole, New Zealand Council for Educational Research and University of Auckland
results.brief_description: Deals with a research project in the Mangere district of South Auckland which sets out to clarify whether parents wished to help their children with reading difficulties, how they could be helped and whether this assistance was of lasting benefit. Presenter Cheryl Sotheran.

results.title: Right out of history: Judy Chicago's 'Dinner party'
results.creator_credit: Johanna Demetrakas, Thom Tyson and Phoenix Films
results.brief_description: For five years Judy Chicago and four hundred artists and researchers worked to create a tribute to women of spirit and accomplishment whose names have been ignored by history. Film-maker Johanna Demetrakos followed their progress towards a work of unprecedented scale and beauty.
results.title_for_label: Right out of history: Judy Chicago’s ‘Dinner party’

results.title: Hangman
results.creator_credit: Les Goldman, Paul Julian and Melrose Productions
results.brief_description: Follows Maurice Ogden’s allegorical poem. A hangman executes the inhabitants of a tow, one by one, without explanation. Fed by the blood of the victims no-one defended - the alien, the one who dared to object, and the Jew - the gallows tree takes root and fills the village square. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
